On 20/12/2007, krn_2k <krn_2k@...> wrote:
>
> Having used and administered both CVS & SVN for years, SVN definitely
> wins out in my experience on many different points. A popular quick
> start guide:
> http://haacked.com/archive/2006/02/22/QuickstartGuidetoSubversiononSourceForge.aspx
> for SVN on sourceforge (http://sourceforge.net/docs/E09).


Thanks, I have today managed to get the SharpNEAT sourcecode into a
sourceforge SVN repository at https://sharpneat.svn.sourceforge.net/

I did however get into a bit of a mess initially because I assumed the
code would go straight into a trunk dir - which it didn't - so I had
to then create one and move the code a couple of times. So now there
is a load of history associated with the freshly uploaded files. Apart
from that I think everything is right and I think I'm understanding
the basic philosophy behind SVN.


> http://ankhsvn.tigris.org/ "AnkhSVN: A Subversion addin for Microsoft
> Visual Studio .NET". I use it extensively, works beautifully (much
> better than the inbuilt Visual Source Safe) although its still handy
> to have tortoisesvn installed as well for the off rare chore.

Thanks I just installed it. The only niggle I've got is that the diff
command seems to do an actual diff as in creating a patch file -
rather than the nice side by side comparison view in Eclipse - I know
I know, I keep going on about Eclipse :)




> There is a .NET plugin for Eclipse floating around but have never used
> it myself.

Yeh I came across a few links to a plugin from Progressive I think it
was. The plugin is dated 2004 and only provides basic C# support such
as syntax colouring/completion - there's no debugger support.

Cheers,

Colin.
